etymology.description: 馄(餛) + 饨(飩) = wonton (stuffed dumpling).
etymology.interpretation: A traditional Chinese stuffed dumpling often served in broth; both characters are semantic-phonetic with the “food” radical. The second syllable is commonly neutralized in Mandarin (hún·tun), and folk etymology sometimes connects it with 混沌 (hùndùn) due to similar sound.
etymology.simplification: Both characters simplified the food radical 飠 to 饣 while retaining their phonetic parts (昆, 屯), yielding 馄 and 饨.

examples.chinese: 我最爱吃馄饨(我最愛吃餛飩)。
examples.english: I love eating wontons the most.

examples.chinese: 这家店的馄饨皮很薄(這家店的餛飩皮很薄)，汤也很鲜(湯也很鮮)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn de húntun pí hěn báo, tāng yě hěn xiān.
examples.english: The wonton wrappers at this shop are very thin, and the soup is very fresh.

examples.chinese: 他点了一碗虾仁馄饨(他點了一碗蝦仁餛飩)，配上海青菜(配上海青菜)。
examples.pinyin: Tā diǎn le yì wǎn xiārén húntun, pèi Shànghǎi qīngcài.
examples.english: He ordered a bowl of shrimp wontons, served with Shanghai greens.
